transcript.clinician: Hi Gabriella, I understand that you're here today because you've been experiencing some low mood.
transcript.patient: Yeah, I just recently I've just... I'm just feeling down a lot and I can't really, like, snap out of it. Like, sometimes if it's happened before, I can just, like, get myself back on track. But recently I'm just finding it really difficult to do.

transcript.clinician: So it sounds like you've been experiencing some low mood and you're kind of struggling to get going a bit.
transcript.patient: Yeah, definitely.

transcript.clinician: You've had low mood in the past, but it's kind of... you've been able to pull yourself out of it before, but more recently you've found that harder. Okay, so I understand that you first went to your GP, who referred you here about two months ago. Can I ask what led you to go to the GP in the first place?
transcript.patient: My long-term boyfriend broke up with me and it was, it was such a shock, like I really wasn't expecting it. It just got me really down. I felt really lonely. And I didn't really want to see people. I just wanted to be in my own space. My mom told me I should probably go to the doctors and he's referred me to you.

transcript.clinician: Okay? So it sounds like you had that breakup and you weren't expecting it, so it kind of came out of the blue a bit and you've been on your own quite a lot. So you're not been seeing people as much. And it sounds like your mum noticed that there's been a bit of a change in you. Okay, and how have things been then since then, since that happened and since you went to the GP?
transcript.patient: I just, nothing's really changed. Nothing's really improved. I just... I feel down, like everything's an effort and feel distant from things. And like I said, I can't snap out of it.

transcript.clinician: Okay, and how did you feel about coming here today?
transcript.patient: I was kind of disappointed in myself because I feel like nobody else my age is doing this. I should have been able to snap out of it, like it's just another thing that I've not really... you know, things that's making me stand out for the wrong reasons.

transcript.clinician: Okay, so you feel like it's kind of odd or unusual to be coming to see a clinical psychologist. I suppose I just want to reassure you that it's absolutely normal to have feelings of depression and anxiety. It's really very common, and it certainly isn't odd or strange at all. So it sounds like it was actually quite hard for you to come here today. So what I guess led you to do that? Because it sounds like maybe there was a lot pushing you against coming here today, but you've managed to come anyway.
transcript.patient: I'm just hoping that it's going to help. I think I didn't really want to admit it because, like, it's just another failure, but my mum was talking to me and she's not really happy with the way I'm behaving. I didn't really want to disappoint her again. And so I thought there's no harm in it. So I came.

transcript.clinician: So it sounds like partly you're doing it then for your mum because you're a bit worried that she isn't pleased with you at the moment.
transcript.patient: Yeah.

transcript.clinician: Well, I think it's great that you've come here. And definitely there's a lot of evidence to suggest that psychological therapy can help depression, and particularly the type of therapy that we're gonna be doing, which is called cognitive behavior therapy. I'll tell you a bit more about that as we go on, but I'm just trying to find out a bit more about you today. So I saw from your notes that you're a medic student.
transcript.patient: Yeah? I'm not currently in uni at the moment, but yeah, last year I was a medical student.

transcript.clinician: Okay, so I guess why, what's the reason that you're not in uni this year?
transcript.patient: It was pretty tough first year, so they then suggested that I took a year out. This is the break.

transcript.clinician: Okay, so just thinking, so that would be about 6 months ago, was it that your year out started? And it sounds then maybe like your first year was also quite tough?
transcript.patient: Yeah, it was. I thought it's tough for everyone, but obviously we all take it in different ways, don't we.

transcript.clinician: And you're planning on returning?
transcript.patient: Yeah, I'm going to have to really.

transcript.clinician: But you don't sound too sure about that.
transcript.patient: No, though I think returning is probably... that's what's going to make everyone happy. And I think, you know, at least I'll be able to finally achieve something and get something right. So yeah, like next year I'm going to... I'll get through that. Yeah.

transcript.clinician: Okay, so it doesn't sound like you want to go back.
transcript.patient: I do. I didn't enjoy it. I just... I just don't feel like me at the moment. And I just, it's a lot of work. It's a lot of pressure. But that's what comes with it. And, you know, it'll work out for the best if I go.

transcript.clinician: Okay, so I guess then there's quite a lot of thoughts and feelings about going back at the moment. I'm just wondering, in the meantime, what are you up to, what have you been doing?
transcript.patient: Well, I haven't really had much on the horizon. My mom, her friends own a restaurant and she suggested that I did a bit of waitressing there, just doing it for a bit of money and stuff because obviously I'm not in uni, so you know, I've done that.

transcript.clinician: Okay, how many shifts have you done there?
transcript.patient: I've only done one so far. Yeah, I don't know whether it's something that I'd probably go back to.

transcript.clinician: Okay, when was that shift?
transcript.patient: It was last week, actually.

transcript.clinician: Okay, and how was it? I suppose I'm intrigued, can you tell me a bit more about that?
transcript.patient: It was, it was different, you know, because it was like... I did enjoy it because it's just a different aspect and I had to speak to people and try to get their orders and try to remember it and stuff. I wasn't very good, but I suppose it was handy to have some money, like get out of the house.

transcript.clinician: So it sounds like you quite enjoyed that. Then what makes you think you weren't very good?
transcript.patient: I just felt slow. And people, sometimes they didn't understand what I was saying, so I'd have to talk louder or quieter, slower. And I got a bit confused sometimes with the orders, and I just don't really think that I'm not really like a friendly... like people don't really think that I'm a friendly person, so they didn't really want to talk to me and stuff. I felt like I was inconveniencing them, by like asking them things and getting things wrong. Yeah, they said that apparently most people get like a few mistakes on their first shift, but then again, she's my mom's friend, so that's probably why she's saying it.

transcript.clinician: So the person who owns the restaurant is your mum's friend. Okay, so you're saying that you think you weren't very good, and that's because you were a bit slow and you got confused with some orders. But you said it's common for people to do that on that first shift. That's what she said to you, but...
transcript.patient: But it's probably just she's just trying to make me feel better. She probably felt sorry for me because I'm obviously not very good at it, like I'm not very good at anything recently. I think she just felt sorry for me.

transcript.clinician: Okay, so I've just been noting down some of those thoughts that you've been having. You kind of say that you feel like you're not very good, you're slow, you're confused with the orders, and you feel like you're inconveniencing her and she feels sorry for you. I suppose I'm wondering, I mean, what makes you think that she feels sorry for you?
transcript.patient: Like I said, she's my mum's friend, and she's obviously feeling sorry for my mum as well because she's got a daughter that's not like anyone else of her age. And she's just like all alone and she's not getting involved. So I think she just feels sorry for me and she doesn't want, like, to upset me. But yeah.

transcript.clinician: When you're having these kind of thoughts, because that's quite a lot of negative thoughts you're describing, how do you feel?
transcript.patient: Just feel empty, I don't... I'm just calling as it is. I'm just calling it as reality. I feel like I'm being honest with myself by just voicing it and not trying to get around hiding it because I know, like, I can see it in myself.

transcript.clinician: So it sounds like you feel like those thoughts are very true then? I mean, if you were going to write them... So I'm going to pick out some of those thoughts you describe. You said 'I'm not very good', and 'I'm inconveniencing them'. How much would you say you believe those on a scale out of 100, where 100 is like, I absolutely believe it and 0 is like, I don't believe it at all?
transcript.patient: I'm about 80, yeah.

transcript.clinician: So you feel quite sure that you definitely believe those, okay? And you said that when you're thinking those thoughts, you start to feel quite empty.
transcript.patient: I just feel distant and like I said, I'm not really myself, I just... It's like I'm not really there, but when I am, I can't even do a good job.

transcript.clinician: And are there any other emotions that you experience?
transcript.patient: I feel drained. I'd say I feel like I'm not in touch with anything, just... it's like everything's going on around me, but I'm just not there. I'm just, it's like I'm just watching.

transcript.clinician: Okay, so you feel empty, distant, you feel drained. And how, when you're feeling these emotions, how do you feel in your body? Kind of what sensations do you notice?
transcript.patient: I don't know how to describe it. I get like, I have a bit of like, like, you know, when you kind of get like butterflies when you're nervous and stuff, kind of get a bit of that.

transcript.clinician: You feel some butterflies? Yeah, did you have butterflies that night when you were at the restaurant?
transcript.patient: Yeah, I was pretty nervous. Then when I got into it, they went away and like it distracted me for a bit. And so obviously I realized that I wasn't doing a very good job.

transcript.clinician: Okay? And you, when you have those emotions, how does it affect your energy levels? Do you feel more energetic, less energetic, or about the same when you feel down?
transcript.patient: Yeah, when you're having those emotions that you were describing... I just feel drained, like didn't even have like the energy to wake up in the morning sometimes, like I just felt pointless, like my body's heavy and I don't want to. Yeah.

transcript.clinician: So it sounds like you feel very tired. You're struggling to wake up. You said it's pointless. And what do you do then when you feel like that? So I guess you just talked about when you wake up in the morning and you feel heavy, and I suppose you've been maybe having some of these thoughts and those emotions potentially the night before, what do you then do? How do you respond to that?
transcript.patient: I just have to get up I suppose. I don't really have a choice because my mum, I live with my mom. I know it's hard for her, so I don't want her to be too worried. So I just... I just try to carry on as normal. It takes longer and I don't want to, but I do, so I'll go on with my routine.

transcript.clinician: So you're a bit slower in getting up, but you are still getting up anyway. And what about your kind of, what do you think about when you're doing that?
transcript.patient: I'm just thinking that nobody else is like me my age, like nobody should be feeling like this. And I'm the only one that does.

transcript.clinician: So it sounds like you think a bit more about the problem and you kind of spend time thinking about...
transcript.patient: How I hate it and I don't want to feel like this, but I do, and nobody else I know does. So it makes me feel even more alone and like getting me even more down. And I just don't want to disappoint anyone. I didn't really want it.

transcript.clinician: Okay, so it sounds like you're trying to toughen up on yourself a little bit, tell yourself to work harder, to be different.
transcript.patient: Okay.

transcript.clinician: And when you start telling yourself that kind of thing, how does that make you feel? Does that make you feel better afterwards or worse?
transcript.patient: Feels worse. Because I still can't snap out of it, like I'm aware it's happening, and I just, and I'm trying, but I just can't. And then, and then it's just another thing that I'm failing at, just another thing that I can't really get.

clinical_note:
**Subjective:**  
Gabriella, a young adult and former medical student currently on a year out from university, presents with persistent low mood and difficulty functioning. She reports feeling "down a lot" and unable to "snap out of it," which is a change from previous episodes of low mood where she was able to recover on her own. The onset of her current symptoms followed an unexpected breakup with her long-term boyfriend, which left her feeling shocked, lonely, and withdrawn. She describes a lack of motivation, feeling that "everything's an effort," and a sense of distance from her surroundings. Gabriella expresses disappointment in herself for seeking help, feeling that her peers are not experiencing similar struggles and perceiving her situation as a personal failure. She reports that her mother encouraged her to seek help and that her mother's concern was a significant factor in her decision to attend the appointment. Gabriella also describes negative self-perceptions, particularly after a recent waitressing shift, feeling slow, confused, and as though she is an inconvenience to others. She rates her belief in these negative thoughts as 80 out of 100. Emotionally, she feels empty, drained, and distant, with physical sensations of "butterflies" when nervous. She reports low energy, difficulty waking up, and a sense of heaviness in her body. Despite these symptoms, she continues to get up and follow her routine, largely to avoid worrying her mother. Gabriella ruminates on her perceived differences from her peers and fears disappointing others, which exacerbates her low mood.

**Objective:**  
Gabriella appears withdrawn and expresses significant negative self-evaluation throughout the session. She is able to articulate her thoughts and feelings clearly, though her affect is flat and she appears emotionally blunted. She reports ongoing functional impairment, including social withdrawal, low motivation, and reduced energy. There is no evidence of psychosis, mania, or acute risk to self or others at this time. She denies any current engagement in university studies and has minimal engagement in work or social activities, having only completed one waitressing shift in the past week. No medication is currently prescribed.

**Assessment:**  
Gabriella is experiencing symptoms consistent with moderate to severe depression, likely precipitated by a significant psychosocial stressor (breakup with her boyfriend) and compounded by academic stress and social withdrawal. She demonstrates pervasive negative automatic thoughts, low self-esteem, anhedonia, low energy, and psychomotor slowing. There is evidence of cognitive distortions, including overgeneralization and personalization, particularly regarding her perceived failures and social interactions. She is currently not taking any psychotropic medication. There is no indication of suicidal ideation or intent at this time, but her sense of hopelessness and self-criticism warrant close monitoring.

**Plan:**  
- Initiate cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) to address negative thought patterns, increase behavioral activation, and improve coping strategies.
- Encourage gradual re-engagement in social and pleasurable activities, starting with manageable goals (e.g., additional waitressing shifts, reconnecting with friends).
- Provide psychoeducation regarding depression, normalizing her experience and reducing self-stigma.
- Involve Gabriella’s mother as appropriate, given her supportive role, while fostering Gabriella’s autonomy.
- Monitor mood symptoms and functional status closely; assess for any emergence of suicidal ideation or significant risk at each session.
- No medication is indicated at this time; reassess need for pharmacotherapy if symptoms do not improve with therapy alone.
- Schedule follow-up appointment in one week to begin CBT and review progress.

data_insights: PHQ-4 and negative affect scores declined as sleep duration stabilized and routine regularity dropped.
Despite increased steps and travel, positive affect remained low and sedentary episodes increased.
PHQ-4 scores and negative affect improved as time at home decreased and travel increased.
Screen unlock episodes peaked as negative affect scores rose, then both declined after 2021-04-09.
Despite high screen time, positive affect scores remained low and even reached zero on 2021-04-07.
Routine regularity and time at home declined, coinciding with increased travel and lower positive affect.
Outgoing and incoming call counts remained low, with no increase despite more significant places visited.
Unique Bluetooth and WiFi devices detected remained low, suggesting limited in-person social contact.
Routine regularity and sleep episode variability both decreased, but sleep duration remained short.
Consistently low time in exercise and green spaces, despite increased total steps and travel distance.
Maximum sleep duration and average sleep duration showed high variability, with frequent short sleep episodes.
PHQ-4 depression and anxiety scores declined after 2021-04-07, mirroring reduced negative affect.
Despite increased steps and travel, sedentary episodes remained high, indicating fragmented activity.
Routine regularity declined sharply after 2021-04-09, coinciding with reduced time at home and increased travel.
Screen unlock duration at home showed high variability, with both very high and very low days.
Number of sleep episodes decreased after 2021-04-05, with more consolidated but still short sleep.
Positive affect scores showed a brief rise after 2021-04-07, but remained low overall.
Maximum screen unlock duration at home decreased after 2021-04-04, mirroring reduced total screen time.
Incoming call count decreased after 2021-04-04, with more days of only one incoming call.
Despite high screen unlock episodes, average unlock duration remained low, indicating brief, frequent device checks.

transcript.clinician: Hi Gabriella, it's good to see you again. I appreciate you coming back for another session. Last time, you shared quite a bit about how you've been feeling since your breakup and the difficulties you're experiencing with motivation and self-esteem. How have things been for you since we last talked?
transcript.patient: Hi, um, thanks. I guess... things are kind of the same, honestly. Like, I still feel pretty stuck most days. I’ve been trying to get out of the house more, like doing that waitressing thing last week, but it didn’t really make me feel better, you know? Just more nervous and kind of overwhelmed. I don’t know if I’m making any progress or just going in circles.

transcript.clinician: It sounds like you're putting in some effort by trying to get out and do new things, but you're feeling that it's not translating into feeling better, and maybe even making you feel more overwhelmed. When you think about the waitressing shift, what do you notice about your thoughts and feelings during or after that experience?
transcript.patient: Yeah, I guess that’s pretty accurate. Um, during the shift, I was really nervous—like, my stomach was doing flips, and I kept thinking I was messing up. I kept telling myself I wasn’t good enough or that I was slow, and I felt kinda embarrassed when I didn’t get things right. Afterward, I just felt... more down, like I failed again, even though everyone said it’s normal for a first shift. I keep thinking maybe I shouldn’t even bother trying if I’m just gonna mess up anyway. It’s like, I want to feel better, but I just end up feeling worse.

transcript.clinician: It sounds like during that shift, your thoughts were quite negative—about your abilities and the way you’re perceived—and those thoughts led to feelings of embarrassment and disappointment afterward. You mentioned feeling like you’re just going in circles and that trying might be pointless because it leads to feeling worse. When you notice those thoughts, how much do you believe them on a scale from 0 to 100? For example, how strongly do you think "I'm just going to mess up" or "I'm not good enough"?
transcript.patient: Um, I’d say... probably around 75 or 80. Like, I know part of me knows I might just be being hard on myself, but another part feels really convinced that I’m just not cut out for these things, or that I’m just going to keep messing up no matter what. It’s kind of frustrating because I want to believe I can get better, but those thoughts feel so real sometimes. And honestly, it’s kind of exhausting to keep fighting that voice in my head.

transcript.clinician: It’s understandable that those persistent, negative thoughts feel very convincing and exhausting. You’re caught between knowing they might not be entirely true and feeling overwhelmed by them anyway. When you think about trying to challenge these thoughts or tell yourself they might not be completely accurate, what kind of response do you usually have? Do you find it easy or hard to question or reframe those beliefs?
transcript.patient: Honestly, it’s pretty hard. I mean, I try to tell myself, like, “Maybe I just need more practice,” or “Everyone makes mistakes,” but then I think, yeah, but what if I really am just not good enough? Or what if I’m just fooling myself? It’s like, I want to believe I can change, but my mind keeps pulling me back to those doubts. It’s kind of like, I want to be more hopeful, but I just don’t feel it yet.

transcript.clinician: That’s a very honest and insightful reflection. It sounds like you’re aware of the possibility of change and even trying to hold onto hope, but those deep-seated doubts keep pulling you back into a negative mindset. When you’re caught in that cycle of doubt and hope, what do you usually do? Do you find yourself ruminating, withdrawing, or perhaps trying to distract yourself?
transcript.patient: Um, I think I mostly just ruminate, honestly. Like, I keep replaying everything in my head—what I said, what I did wrong, how I probably disappointed everyone, especially my mom. Sometimes I just want to distract myself, but I feel guilty about not doing anything productive or not trying hard enough to fix it. So, yeah, I guess I mostly just get stuck in my head, and that makes me feel even more tired and hopeless. It’s like I can’t really escape those thoughts, even if I want to.

transcript.clinician: It sounds like your mind tends to get stuck in a loop of these negative thoughts, especially about disappointing your mom and feeling tired and hopeless. That rumination seems to drain your energy and make it harder to see a way forward. When you notice yourself ruminating, what do you think might help, even just a little, to break that cycle? Or what have you tried that maybe offers some relief, even temporarily?
transcript.patient: Honestly, I haven’t really figured out what works yet. Sometimes I try to distract myself by watching shows or scrolling on my phone, but then I just feel guilty because I’m not doing anything meaningful. Other times, I just sit there and think about everything, which makes it worse. I guess I haven’t found a good way to stop those thoughts from taking over. It’s like, I want to find something that can help me feel a little better, even if it’s just for a moment, but I don’t know what that is yet.

transcript.clinician: It makes sense that you're seeking something to help you feel even briefly better, but haven't quite found what works yet. That frustration is understandable. Sometimes, finding small, manageable activities that don’t feel overwhelming can be a helpful starting point. Have you noticed any activities or moments, even small ones, that have brought you a little relief or distraction in the past? Or perhaps things you’ve enjoyed before but haven't done recently?
transcript.patient: Hmm, I guess... I used to like drawing or writing in my journal, but I haven't really done either in a while. When I was younger, I’d spend hours just sketching or writing stories, and it made me forget about everything for a bit. But now, I just feel like I don’t have the energy or motivation to do those things anymore. It’s like, even if I want to, I just can’t seem to get started or find the interest. I wonder if I should try again, but I’m not sure if it’ll make a difference.

transcript.clinician: Reconnecting with activities like drawing or journaling that once brought you some peace sounds like a meaningful idea. It’s understandable to feel hesitant, especially when motivation and energy are low. Sometimes, just allowing yourself to engage in these activities without pressure—maybe for a few minutes—can help gently break the cycle of rumination. How do you feel about giving yourself permission to try again, even if it’s just a small step?
transcript.patient: I guess I could try, yeah. Like, maybe I don’t have to do it perfectly or spend hours on it. Just, you know, a little bit, just to see if it helps me feel a bit more... grounded or something. It’s just hard to believe it’ll actually make a difference, but I suppose I can give it a shot. I don’t want to keep feeling like this all the time, so maybe it’s worth trying.

transcript.clinician: That sounds like a very reasonable and compassionate approach—giving yourself permission to engage in those activities without the pressure of doing it perfectly. Even small steps can sometimes lead to noticeable changes over time. If you decide to try drawing or journaling, perhaps setting a timer for just a few minutes could make it feel more manageable. Would you be willing to share how it goes next time, or if you notice any small shifts in how you’re feeling?
transcript.patient: Yeah, I think I could do that. I mean, it’s not like I have much else going on right now, so I might as well try. I guess I’ll start with just a few minutes, like you said, and see if it helps. It’s kind of embarrassing to even admit I’m trying this, but maybe it’s worth a shot. Thanks for suggesting it. I’ll let you know how it goes next time.

transcript.clinician: That’s a very brave and honest decision, Gabriella. Remember, taking even small steps like that is a positive move forward, and there’s no shame in trying. It’s all about finding what works for you, one step at a time. I look forward to hearing how it goes next time. For now, is there anything else you’d like to share or explore today?
transcript.patient: Honestly, I’m not sure. I feel like I’ve been just going over the same stuff in my head, and I don’t know if there’s anything new I want to talk about. But maybe, I guess, I’m still struggling with feeling like I’m not good enough—like, even if I try those little things, I still doubt myself a lot. It’s kind of frustrating because I want to believe I can get better, but I just don’t know how to really believe it yet. Maybe that’s something I need to work on more.

transcript.clinician:
It’s understandable to feel that way, Gabriella. Doubting yourself and feeling not good enough can be very persistent, especially when those thoughts have been part of your experience for a while. Recognizing that this is something you want to work on is an important insight. Building that belief in yourself often takes time and small successes, even if they feel minor at first. 

Would you be open to exploring some strategies or exercises that might help gradually strengthen your self-belief? Or perhaps discussing ways to challenge those doubts when they come up?
transcript.patient: Yeah, I think I’d be willing to try that. I mean, I don’t really know how to challenge those doubts, though. It’s like, I hear them, and I just believe them most of the time. But maybe if I had some kind of way to, I don’t know, talk back to them or remind myself of other things, it could help. I just don’t really know where to start with that, or if it even works.

transcript.clinician:
That’s a very honest and thoughtful reflection. Challenging those doubts can feel difficult, especially when they seem so convincing. A common approach in CBT is to identify these negative thoughts, examine the evidence for and against them, and then develop more balanced or realistic perspectives. It’s like having a conversation with that inner critic, where you gently question its assumptions and remind yourself of your strengths or positive qualities.

Would you like to work through an example of one of your doubts—say, the thought “I’m not good enough”—and see how we might challenge it together?
transcript.patient: Yeah, I think that could be helpful. I mean, I guess I do have some moments where I realize I’m not as terrible as I think—I mean, I did get through the shift, even if I was nervous and slow. But then I just tell myself that it was just luck or that I was lucky they were patient with me. So, I don’t know, how do I really challenge that kind of thought? It feels like I’m just making excuses, but I don’t want to believe I’m just fooling myself either.

transcript.clinician:
That’s a very insightful observation—you recognize your efforts and some moments of competence, but then dismiss them as luck or patience. Challenging that kind of thought involves looking at the evidence more objectively and considering alternative explanations. 

For example, when you think, “It was just luck,” you can ask yourself, “What evidence do I have that supports or contradicts that?” Have there been times when you managed tasks or handled situations well, even if you were nervous? Or perhaps moments where others acknowledged your effort or progress? 

Would you like to try framing some evidence for and against that thought?
transcript.patient: Yeah, I suppose there have been times when I did okay, even if I was nervous. Like, I did remember some of the orders, and people didn’t seem too annoyed with me. And my mom said I was doing fine, even if I felt like I was messing up. But then I think, maybe she’s just being nice or trying to make me feel better. So, I guess I can see that there’s some truth in what you’re saying, but it’s hard to really believe it.

transcript.clinician:
Exactly, Gabriella. You’re already doing a great job of examining the evidence—recognizing that you did some things right, and that others, like your mom, offered reassurance. The challenge is in balancing that evidence against the doubts that tell you otherwise. It’s normal for those doubts to feel very strong, especially when you’re feeling low. 

A helpful next step can be to create a more balanced thought—something like, “I may have been nervous and made some mistakes, but I also remembered some things and handled some situations okay.” Does that resonate with you? Would you like to try crafting a balanced thought together?
transcript.patient: Yes, I think I could try that. It’s kind of strange, because part of me still feels like I’m just pretending or that I’m fooling myself, but I guess I can see that I did some things right. Maybe I can tell myself that even if I was nervous, I still managed to do some things okay, and that’s not nothing. I’ll try to keep that in mind next time those doubts come up. Thanks for helping me see that there’s a different way to look at it.

transcript.clinician:
That’s a really thoughtful and balanced way to approach those doubts, Gabriella. Acknowledging both the difficulties and the successes can help you build a more realistic and compassionate view of yourself. Remember, challenging negative thoughts is a process, and it’s normal for doubts to linger. With practice, it can become easier to see your efforts and progress more clearly. 

Would you like to set a small goal for yourself before our next session, maybe related to practicing this kind of balanced thinking or engaging in one of your favorite activities again?
transcript.patient: Yeah, I think I’d like to try that. Maybe I can practice challenging my doubts when they come up, just like we talked about, and also try to do a little drawing or writing in my journal. Even if it’s just for a few minutes, I think it might help me feel a bit more connected to myself. I’ll see how it goes, and I’ll let you know next time. Thanks for all the support today.

transcript.clinician:
That sounds like a very practical and compassionate plan, Gabriella. Practicing challenging your doubts when they arise and reconnecting with your creative outlets are excellent steps toward feeling more grounded and confident. Remember, progress can be gradual, and every small effort counts. I look forward to hearing how it goes next time. 

Thank you for sharing honestly today. See you next time.
transcript.patient: Thank you. I appreciate it. I’ll try my best. See you next time.

transcript.clinician: You're very welcome, Gabriella. I admire your willingness to try and your thoughtful approach. Take care, and I look forward to hearing about your progress next time. See you then.
transcript.patient: Goodbye.

clinical_note:
**Subjective:**  
Gabriella returns for follow-up after her recent breakup, continuing to report persistent low mood, decreased motivation, and low self-esteem. She describes feeling “stuck” and notes that efforts to engage in new activities, such as a recent waitressing shift, have left her feeling more nervous and overwhelmed rather than improved. During the shift, she experienced significant anxiety, self-critical thoughts (“I’m not good enough,” “I’m just going to mess up”), and embarrassment, which persisted afterward despite reassurance from others. Gabriella rates her belief in these negative thoughts as 75-80/100, acknowledging some awareness that she may be overly self-critical but finding it difficult to challenge these beliefs. She reports frequent rumination, particularly about disappointing her mother, and describes feeling exhausted and hopeless as a result. Attempts at distraction (e.g., watching shows, using her phone) provide little relief and often lead to guilt about not being productive. Gabriella identifies that she previously enjoyed drawing and journaling but currently lacks the motivation or energy to engage in these activities. She expresses willingness to try re-engaging with these hobbies in small, manageable steps and is open to practicing more balanced thinking to challenge her self-doubt. She remains frustrated by her persistent feelings of inadequacy but is interested in learning strategies to strengthen her self-belief.

**Objective:**  
Gabriella is alert, oriented, and cooperative throughout the session. Her affect is subdued but congruent with her reported mood. Speech is coherent and goal-directed. She demonstrates good insight into her thought patterns and is able to articulate her struggles with negative self-talk and rumination. No evidence of psychosis, mania, or suicidal ideation is present. No medication is currently prescribed. Gabriella is not currently engaged in any structured behavioral activation or formal therapy outside of these sessions.

**Assessment:**  
Gabriella continues to experience symptoms consistent with moderate depressive disorder, characterized by persistent low mood, anhedonia, low self-esteem, and significant cognitive distortions (e.g., negative self-appraisal, catastrophizing, and rumination). She demonstrates some motivation to improve and is able to reflect insightfully on her thought patterns, though she finds it difficult to challenge entrenched negative beliefs. Social withdrawal and avoidance behaviors are present, though she is making efforts to re-engage with activities. No acute safety concerns are identified at this time. Gabriella is not currently taking any psychotropic medications.

**Plan:**  
- Continue supportive psychotherapy with a focus on cognitive-behavioral strategies, including identification and challenging of negative automatic thoughts.
- Encourage Gabriella to re-engage with previously enjoyed activities (drawing, journaling) in a low-pressure, time-limited manner (e.g., a few minutes at a time) to promote behavioral activation and provide opportunities for positive reinforcement.
- Assign homework to practice balanced thinking: when negative self-doubt arises, Gabriella will attempt to identify evidence for and against these thoughts and develop more compassionate, realistic self-appraisals.
- Explore additional strategies for managing rumination and self-criticism in future sessions, including mindfulness or self-compassion exercises as appropriate.
- Monitor mood, motivation, and engagement with activities at next session; assess for any changes in risk or emergence of new symptoms.
- No medication indicated at this time; continue to evaluate for potential need based on symptom progression and Gabriella’s preferences.
- Schedule follow-up session in one week. Gabriella will report back on her experiences with drawing/journaling and practicing balanced thinking. 

Gabriella is encouraged to reach out if her symptoms worsen or if she experiences any thoughts of self-harm. She expresses understanding and willingness to try the agreed-upon strategies.

transcript.clinician: Hi Gabriella, it’s good to see you again. I appreciate you coming back for another session. Last time, you shared quite a bit about how you’ve been feeling since your breakup and the difficulties you’re experiencing with motivation and self-esteem. How have things been for you since we last talked?
transcript.patient: Hi, thanks. Um, honestly, not much has changed. I still feel pretty stuck most days, you know? I tried going back to that waitressing thing last week, but honestly, it just made me more nervous and overwhelmed. I don’t know if I’m really making any progress or just going in circles, really. It’s kind of frustrating.

transcript.clinician: It sounds like despite your efforts to get out there and try new things, you're feeling like it's not helping much and perhaps even making you feel more overwhelmed. When you think about that waitressing shift, what thoughts or feelings come up during or after the experience?
transcript.patient: Yeah, exactly. During the shift, I was, um, really nervous—like, my stomach was doing flips, and I kept thinking I was messing up. I kept telling myself I wasn’t good enough or that I was slow, and I felt kind of embarrassed when I didn’t get things right. Afterward, I just felt… more down, like I failed again, even though everyone said it’s normal for a first shift. I keep thinking maybe I shouldn’t even bother trying if I’m just gonna mess up anyway. It’s like, I want to feel better, but I just end up feeling worse.

transcript.clinician: It sounds like during the shift, your thoughts were quite negative—about your abilities and the way you're perceived—and those thoughts led to feelings of embarrassment and disappointment afterward. You mentioned feeling like you're just going in circles and that trying might be pointless because it leads to feeling worse. When you notice those thoughts, how much do you believe them on a scale from 0 to 100? For example, how strongly do you think "I'm just going to mess up" or "I'm not good enough"?
transcript.patient: Um, I’d say… probably around 75 or 80. Like, I know part of me knows I might just be being hard on myself, but another part feels really convinced that I’m just not cut out for these things, or that I’m just going to keep messing up no matter what. It’s kind of frustrating because I want to believe I can get better, but those thoughts feel so real sometimes. And honestly, it’s kind of exhausting to keep fighting that voice in my head.

transcript.clinician: That’s very understandable. Those persistent, negative thoughts can feel very convincing and exhausting. You’re caught between knowing they might not be entirely true and feeling overwhelmed by them anyway. When you think about trying to challenge these thoughts or tell yourself they might not be completely accurate, what kind of response do you usually have? Do you find it easy or hard to question or reframe those beliefs?
transcript.patient: Honestly, it’s pretty hard. I mean, I try to tell myself, like, “Maybe I just need more practice,” or “Everyone makes mistakes,” but then I think, yeah, but what if I really am just not good enough? Or what if I’m just fooling myself? It’s like, I want to believe I can change, but my mind keeps pulling me back to those doubts. It’s kind of like, I want to be more hopeful, but I just don’t feel it yet.

transcript.clinician: That’s a very honest and insightful reflection. It sounds like you’re aware of the possibility of change and even trying to hold onto hope, but those deep-seated doubts keep pulling you back into a negative mindset. When you’re caught in that cycle of doubt and hope, what do you usually do? Do you find yourself ruminating, withdrawing, or perhaps trying to distract yourself?
transcript.patient: Yeah, I think I mostly just ruminate, honestly. Like, I keep replaying everything in my head—what I said, what I did wrong, how I probably disappointed everyone, especially my mom. Sometimes I just want to distract myself, but I feel guilty about not doing anything productive or not trying hard enough to fix it. So, yeah, I guess I mostly just get stuck in my head, and that makes me feel even more tired and hopeless. It’s like, I can’t really escape those thoughts, even if I want to.

transcript.clinician: It sounds like your mind tends to get stuck in a loop of these negative thoughts, especially about disappointing your mom and feeling tired and hopeless. That rumination seems to drain your energy and make it harder to see a way forward. When you notice yourself ruminating, what do you think might help, even just a little, to break that cycle? Or what have you tried that maybe offers some relief, even temporarily?
transcript.patient: Honestly, I haven’t really figured out what works yet. Sometimes I try to distract myself by watching shows or scrolling on my phone, but then I just feel guilty because I’m not doing anything meaningful. Other times, I just sit there and think about everything, which makes it worse. I guess I haven’t found a good way to stop those thoughts from taking over. It’s like, I want to find something that can help me feel a little better, even if it’s just for a moment, but I don’t know what that is yet.

transcript.clinician: It makes sense that you're seeking something to help you feel even briefly better, but haven't quite found what works yet. That frustration is understandable. Sometimes, finding small, manageable activities that don’t feel overwhelming can be a helpful starting point. Have you noticed any activities or moments, even small ones, that have brought you a little relief or distraction in the past? Or perhaps things you’ve enjoyed before but haven't done recently?
transcript.patient: Hmm, I guess... I used to like drawing or writing in my journal, but I haven't really done either in a while. When I was younger, I’d spend hours just sketching or writing stories, and it made me forget about everything for a bit. But now, I just feel like I don’t have the energy or motivation to do those things anymore. It’s like, even if I want to, I just can’t seem to get started or find the interest. I wonder if I should try again, but I’m not sure if it’ll make a difference.

transcript.clinician: Reconnecting with activities like drawing or journaling that once brought you some peace sounds like a meaningful idea. It’s understandable to feel hesitant, especially when motivation and energy are low. Sometimes, just allowing yourself to engage in these activities without pressure—maybe for a few minutes—can help gently break the cycle of rumination. How do you feel about giving yourself permission to try again, even if it’s just a small step?
transcript.patient: I guess I could try, yeah. Like, maybe I don’t have to do it perfectly or spend hours on it. Just, you know, a little bit, just to see if it helps me feel a bit more... grounded or something. It’s just hard to believe it’ll actually make a difference, but I suppose I can give it a shot. I don’t want to keep feeling like this all the time, so maybe it’s worth trying.

transcript.clinician: That sounds like a very reasonable and compassionate approach—giving yourself permission to engage in those activities without the pressure of doing it perfectly. Even small steps can sometimes lead to noticeable changes over time. If you decide to try drawing or journaling, perhaps setting a timer for just a few minutes could make it feel more manageable. Would you be willing to share how it goes next time, or if you notice any small shifts in how you’re feeling?
transcript.patient: Yeah, I think I could do that. I mean, it’s not like I have much else going on right now, so I might as well try. I guess I’ll start with just a few minutes, like you said, and see if it helps. It’s kind of embarrassing to even admit I’m trying this, but maybe it’s worth a shot. Thanks for suggesting it. I’ll let you know how it goes next time.

transcript.clinician: That’s a very brave and honest decision, Gabriella. Remember, taking even small steps like that is a positive move forward, and there’s no shame in trying. It’s all about finding what works for you, one step at a time. I look forward to hearing how it goes next time. For now, is there anything else you’d like to share or explore today?
transcript.patient: I guess, um, I don’t know. I feel like I’ve just been going over the same stuff in my head, and I’m not really sure if there’s anything new I want to talk about. But I guess I’m still struggling with feeling like I’m not good enough—like, even if I do those little things, I still doubt myself a lot. It’s kind of frustrating because I want to believe I can get better, but I just don’t know how to really believe it yet. Maybe that’s something I need to work on more.

transcript.clinician:
It’s completely understandable to feel that way, Gabriella. Doubting yourself and feeling not good enough can be very persistent, especially when those thoughts have been part of your experience for a while. Recognizing that this is something you want to work on is an important insight. Building that belief in yourself often takes time and small successes, even if they feel minor at first.

Would you be open to exploring some strategies or exercises that might help gradually strengthen your self-belief? Or perhaps discussing ways to challenge those doubts when they come up?
transcript.patient: Yeah, I think I’d be willing to try that. I mean, I don’t really know how to challenge those doubts, though. It’s like, I hear them, and I just believe them most of the time. But maybe if I had some kind of way to, I don’t know, talk back to them or remind myself of other things, it could help. I just don’t really know where to start with that, or if it even works.

transcript.clinician:
That’s a very honest and thoughtful reflection. Challenging those doubts can feel difficult, especially when they seem so convincing. A common approach in CBT is to identify these negative thoughts, examine the evidence for and against them, and then develop more balanced or realistic perspectives. It’s like having a conversation with that inner critic, where you gently question its assumptions and remind yourself of your strengths or positive qualities.

Would you like to work through an example of one of your doubts—say, the thought “I’m not good enough”—and see how we might challenge it together?
transcript.patient: Yeah, I think that could be helpful. I mean, I guess I do have some moments where I realize I’m not as terrible as I think—I mean, I did get through the shift, even if I was nervous and slow. But then I just tell myself that it was just luck or that I was lucky they were patient with me. So, I don’t know, how do I really challenge that kind of thought? It feels like, I’m just making excuses, but I don’t want to believe I’m just fooling myself either.

transcript.clinician:
That’s a very insightful observation—you recognize your efforts and some moments of competence, but then dismiss them as luck or patience. Challenging that kind of thought involves looking at the evidence more objectively and considering alternative explanations. 

For example, when you think, “It was just luck,” you can ask yourself, “What evidence do I have that supports or contradicts that?” Have there been times when you managed tasks or handled situations well, even if you were nervous? Or perhaps moments where others acknowledged your effort or progress? 

Would you like to try framing some evidence for and against that thought?
transcript.patient: Yeah, I suppose there have been times when I did okay, even if I was nervous. Like, I did remember some of the orders, and people didn’t seem too annoyed with me. And my mom said I was doing fine, even if I felt like I was messing up. But then I think, maybe she’s just being nice or trying to make me feel better. So, I guess I can see that there’s some truth in what you’re saying, but it’s hard to really believe it.

transcript.clinician:
Exactly, Gabriella. You’re already doing a great job of examining the evidence—recognizing that you did some things right, and that others, like your mom, offered reassurance. The challenge is in balancing that evidence against the doubts that tell you otherwise. It’s normal for those doubts to feel very strong, especially when you’re feeling low.

A helpful next step can be to create a more balanced thought—something like, “I may have been nervous and made some mistakes, but I also remembered some things and handled some situations okay.” Does that resonate with you? Would you like to try crafting a balanced thought together?
transcript.patient: Yes, I think I could try that. It’s kind of strange, because part of me still feels like I’m just pretending or that I’m fooling myself, but I guess I can see that I did some things right. Maybe I can tell myself that even if I was nervous, I still managed to do some things okay, and that’s not nothing. I’ll try to keep that in mind next time those doubts come up. Thanks for helping me see that there’s a different way to look at it.

transcript.clinician:
That’s a very thoughtful and balanced way to approach those doubts, Gabriella. Acknowledging both the difficulties and the successes can help you build a more realistic and compassionate view of yourself. Remember, challenging negative thoughts is a process, and it’s normal for doubts to linger. With practice, it can become easier to see your efforts and progress more clearly.

Would you like to set a small goal for yourself before our next session, maybe related to practicing this kind of balanced thinking or engaging in one of your favorite activities again?
transcript.patient: Yeah, I think I’d like to try that. Maybe I can practice challenging my doubts when they come up, just like we talked about, and also try to do a little drawing or writing in my journal. Even if it’s just for a few minutes, I think it might help me feel a bit more connected to myself. I’ll see how it goes, and I’ll let you know next time. Thanks for all the support today.

transcript.clinician:
That sounds like a very practical and compassionate plan, Gabriella. Practicing challenging your doubts when they arise and reconnecting with your creative outlets are excellent steps toward feeling more grounded and confident. Remember, progress can be gradual, and every small effort counts. I look forward to hearing how it goes next time.

Thank you for sharing honestly today. See you next time.
transcript.patient: Thank you. I appreciate it. I’ll try my best. See you next time.

transcript.clinician: You're very welcome, Gabriella. I admire your willingness to try and your thoughtful approach. Take care, and I look forward to hearing about your progress next time. See you then.
transcript.patient: Goodbye.

clinical_note:
**Subjective:**  
Gabriella returns for follow-up after her previous session, where she discussed ongoing difficulties with low mood, poor motivation, and self-esteem issues following a recent breakup. She reports that her mood and motivation remain largely unchanged, describing herself as feeling “stuck” and frustrated by a perceived lack of progress. Gabriella attempted to return to work as a waitress but found the experience overwhelming and anxiety-provoking, with persistent negative self-talk (“I’m not good enough,” “I’m just going to mess up”). She rates her belief in these negative thoughts as 75-80/100, acknowledging some awareness that she may be overly self-critical but feeling largely convinced by these thoughts. Gabriella describes significant rumination, particularly about disappointing others (notably her mother), and reports that this mental loop is exhausting and contributes to feelings of hopelessness. She has tried distraction (e.g., watching shows, using her phone) but feels guilty for not being productive. She identifies a loss of interest and energy for previously enjoyable activities such as drawing and journaling, though she expresses some openness to re-engaging with these activities in a low-pressure way. Gabriella is interested in learning strategies to challenge her negative self-beliefs and is willing to try cognitive restructuring and behavioral activation, though she remains skeptical about their potential effectiveness.

**Objective:**  
Gabriella is alert, oriented, and engaged throughout the session. Her affect is congruent with her reported mood—she appears downcast, with low energy and some psychomotor slowing. Speech is soft but coherent and goal-directed. Thought content is notable for persistent negative self-evaluation and hopelessness, but there is no evidence of psychosis, mania, or active suicidal ideation. Insight and judgment are intact; she is able to reflect thoughtfully on her experiences and is open to therapeutic suggestions. No medication is currently prescribed. No acute safety concerns identified during the session.

**Assessment:**  
Gabriella continues to experience symptoms consistent with moderate major depressive disorder, characterized by low mood, anhedonia, low self-esteem, excessive rumination, and cognitive distortions (e.g., catastrophizing, all-or-nothing thinking). She demonstrates some motivation for change and insight into her difficulties but is struggling to break the cycle of negative thinking and avoidance. There is no current evidence of psychosis, mania, or acute risk to self or others. She is not currently taking any psychotropic medication. Her willingness to try behavioral activation (drawing, journaling) and cognitive restructuring is a positive prognostic indicator, though her skepticism and low self-efficacy may present ongoing challenges.

**Plan:**  
- Continue weekly psychotherapy sessions with a focus on cognitive-behavioral strategies, including:
  - Cognitive restructuring: Practice identifying, examining, and challenging negative automatic thoughts (e.g., “I’m not good enough”) and developing more balanced, evidence-based self-appraisals.
  - Behavioral activation: Encourage Gabriella to re-engage with previously enjoyable activities (drawing, journaling) in a low-pressure, time-limited manner (e.g., set a timer for a few minutes) to reduce rumination and increase positive reinforcement.
- Set small, achievable goals for the upcoming week: Gabriella will attempt to draw or journal for a few minutes and practice challenging negative thoughts as they arise, noting any changes in mood or self-perception.
- Monitor for any emergence of suicidal ideation or significant functional decline; provide crisis resources as needed.
- No medication changes at this time; continue to assess for potential benefit of pharmacotherapy if symptoms persist or worsen.
- Reassess progress and barriers at next session; explore additional cognitive and behavioral strategies as appropriate.
- Encourage Gabriella to share her experiences with these interventions at the next appointment to collaboratively evaluate their impact and adjust the treatment plan as needed.

Number of unique Bluetooth and WiFi devices sensed increased after 5/25, suggesting more varied environments.

Digital engagement at home dropped sharply on 5/28, matching peak outdoor activity and travel distance.
Significant increase in physical activity after 5/19, with sharp rises in total distance and steps.
Time in exercise and green spaces peaked on 5/28, coinciding with highest step count.
Screen unlock duration and episodes at home dropped sharply on 5/28, matching a peak in outdoor activity.
Routine regularity dropped on 5/28, aligning with increased travel and new significant places visited.
Sleep became more fragmented after 5/19, with decreased maximum sleep duration and increased awake duration.
Median number of significant places increased after 5/21, suggesting broader social or environmental engagement.
Outgoing and incoming call counts increased after 5/10, indicating more frequent social contact.
Missed call and outgoing call count variability increased after 5/10, suggesting fluctuating social responsiveness.
Sleep duration and sleep episode count both show cyclic trends, indicating irregular sleep patterns.
Number of sleep episodes decreased after 5/10, while total sleep duration remained variable.
Time at home decreased as total distance and number of significant places increased post-5/19.
Digital engagement at home decreased after 5/10, with shorter and less frequent screen unlocks.
Routine regularity is generally high but interrupted by brief drops, suggesting occasional disruptions.
